perturbation.original_text: (b) Payment of Promotion Fee. Exact, within thirty (30) days after the end of each Calendar Quarter of the Term, shall deliver to Pfizer a consolidated report in the form of and containing the information necessary to confirm the calculation of the Promotion Fee for such Calendar Quarter, together with the underlying spreadsheets with respect to such Calendar Quarter. The Promotion Fee due with respect to such Calendar Quarter and reflected on the consolidated report shall be remitted at the time such report is made.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) Payment of Promotion Fee. Exact, within ninety (90) days after the end of each Calendar Quarter of the Term, shall deliver to Pfizer a consolidated report in the form of and containing the information necessary to confirm the calculation of the Promotion Fee for such Calendar Quarter, together with the underlying spreadsheets with respect to such Calendar Quarter. The Promotion Fee due with respect to such Calendar Quarter and reflected on the consolidated report shall be remitted at the time such report is made.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies payment within 30 days of the end of each quarter. The modification extends this to 90 days. Many jurisdictions and standard business practices support shorter payment terms for service fees; extending it to 90 days without reasonable justification could be viewed as an unreasonably long delay, especially if it negatively impacts Pfizer's cash flow. This creates a legal contradiction since payment terms must be fair and commercially reasonable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring fair and reasonable terms; potential violation of state-specific prompt payment laws if applicable.

perturbation.original_text: 7.1 Confidentiality. Except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or otherwise agreed in writing, the Parties agree that, for the term of this Agreement and for five (5) years thereafter, each Party (the “Receiving Party”), receiving any Confidential Information of the other Party (the “Disclosing Party”) hereunder shall keep such Confidential Information confidential and shall not publish or otherwise disclose or use such Confidential Information for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 7.1 Confidentiality. Except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or otherwise agreed in writing, the Parties agree that, for the term of this Agreement and for one (1) year thereafter, each Party (the “Receiving Party”), receiving any Confidential Information of the other Party (the “Disclosing Party”) hereunder shall keep such Confidential Information confidential and shall not publish or otherwise disclose or use such Confidential Information for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original confidentiality clause extends for five years post-agreement. Reducing this to one year weakens protection of trade secrets and proprietary information. Trade secrets may require longer protection to maintain their value and competitive advantage. This creates a legal contradiction with the reasonable measures required to protect trade secrets under both federal (Defend Trade Secrets Act) and state laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA); state trade secret laws (e.g., Uniform Trade Secrets Act).

perturbation.original_text: 8.6 Termination for Change of Control. This Agreement may be terminated by either Party upon six (6) months written notice following a Change of Control of Exact; provided that such notice is given within thirty (30) days of the consummation of such Change of Control.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.6 Termination for Change of Control. This Agreement may be terminated by either Party upon one (1) months written notice following a Change of Control of Exact; provided that such notice is given within sixty (60) days of the consummation of such Change of Control.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows termination with six months' notice, but notice has to be delivered within 30 days of a change in control. This was modified to one months' notice with delivery allowed to 60 days. Federal regulations require sufficient transition periods and cannot violate SEC guidelines.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Regulations, SEC regulations on publicly traded companies
